Dialogue.Stage Direction: On a patch of sand surrounded on two sides by large stone slabs, an old man is sitting and meditating. He wears a blue gem on a string around his neck. Meanwhile, Nyssa comes out of the interior of the Tardis wearing a circular striped skirt over a pair of knee-length shorts and a bright blouse, and shows her new costume off to the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Well?
We're not where we're supposed to be.
Where are we?
I don't know. There are traces of anti-matter.
Omega?
Oh, highly unlikely he's still alive. It's not a navigational malfunction either.
Shall I wake Tegan?
No, no, there's no danger, although it's puzzling. It's very puzzling.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan still sleeps as Nyssa fetches a large reference book.

Dialogue.Line: (reads) Planet G139901KB in the Scrampus system. Local name, Manussa. Type 314S. Inhabited. Atmosphere ninety eight percent Terra normal, gravity ninety six percent Terra normal.
Well, at least we can breath the air. I suppose that's something. You look different.
Yes, Doctor.
The question is, how did we get here?

There's more. (reads) Third planet in the Federation system. Status, colony. Former homeworld Manussan Empire, destroyed. Former homeworld Sumaran Empire, destroyed. Present economy, subsistence agriculture and tourism.
Former homeworld?
Manussan Empire.
No, no, the other one.
Sumaran Empire.
This is serious. Someone's been playing around. Who set the coordinates?
Well, you did.
No, no, no. Earlier, I was trying to teach both of you to read the star charts. Now, one of you actually read out the coordinates for me to set. Who was it?
I can't remember.
It was Tegan.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan is having a dream about being in a cavern temple, and walking up some steps into an giant open snake's jaw. She screams, and wakes herself up.

We are shown a silver snake with a blue gem in its mouth. A young man walks down a spiral staircase into the room. Everyone embarrass  Martin Clunes by saying Hi! He picks up the sculpture and sits on a fur-covered chaise-longue. Meanwhile, Nyssa is at Tegan's side. The Doctor stands in the doorway.

Dialogue.Line: Tegan, what's the matter? What happened?
It was the dream.
The dream? What dream?
I can't, I can't remember. I can never remember.
But you've had this dream, this particular dream, before.
Doctor, stop it.
Haven't you?
Yes.
Always the same dream?
Yes, I think so. The images fade so quickly.
But the same feelings of fear remain.
Doctor. It doesn't matter. You're awake now. It was only a dream.
No, it wasn't, somehow.
Tegan
She means it. I think she could be right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A woman enters to see her son lounging about with the statuette.

Dialogue.Line: Lon, you're not dressed yet. Ambril will be here in a moment. He promised to show us the caves this morning. Have you forgotten?
No, mother, I hadn't forgotten.
Well, then. We must make the effort.
Must we?
Well of course we must.
Why?
It is expected of us. You are the Federator's son. Come, Lon. What's wrong?
The Federator's son is bored.
Now then, Tegan, where are we?
What?
Very simple question, where are we?
Well, aren't we on Earth?
No, we're not. So?
Well how should I know?
Think!
Doctor.
Please, Tegan, think. Reach into the back of your mind.
Are we on Manussa?
Good.
Are we?
Yes, we are.
How did I know that?
Manussa, formerly homeworld of the Sumaran Empire which may or may not ring a bell. Does it, Tegan? The Sumaran Empire?
I agree Ambril can be rather trying. On the whole, you know, I preferred his predecessor. Now what was the man's name? Oh, he was completely dotty, but much more fun.
It's not just Ambril, mother, it's all of it. The ceremony and everything. It's all such nonsense, isn't it.
Is it?
Of course it is. And all so long ago. The Mara was destroyed five hundred years ago and yet we're still celebrating it. Why?
Oh, once every ten years.
It occurs to me that the whole thing is kept going solely to remind the people here how much better life is under the rule of the Federation.
And so it is.
Is it?
Of course it is. Life under the Mara must have been gruesome in the extreme. I mean, look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She takes the snake statuette from Lon.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, it is grotesque. You ought to take more interest in our heritage.
Why?

Well, it's the root of our culture. The Legend of the Return. Although, now what was the man's name? Well, the Director before Ambril, he didn't think it was just a legend. He thought the Mara really would return.
Am I now supposed to take the ramblings of a mad man seriously?
He didn't ramble.
The Mara was destroyed, not banished to another dimension. It won't return in a dream or in any other form.
If you say so.
I think I just have.
Well, it made a good story. Quite made my hair stand on end. Ambril's predecessor was rather good value, even if he was talking nonsense.
Is this necessary?
Yes. We must recover Tegan's dream, and simple hypnosis is the quickest way.
But why must we?

Dreams are important, Nyssa. Never underestimate them. Once a man fell asleep, dreamt he was a frog. When he woke up he didn't know if he was a man who dreamt he was a frog, or a frog who was now dreaming he was a man.
I'm still possessed, aren't I, Doctor. The Mara from the world of the Kinda is still inside my head somewhere, isn't it.
We'll have to see.
But you think so.
It does seem likely. I'm sorry.
But where?
Well, obviously below the threshold of conscious thought. I would imagine that when awake your mind is still strong enough to resist, but in sleep it loosens its grip and battle is joined.
In my dreams?
Yes.
The battle for what?
For control. Come over here.
That's why you misread the coordinates.
It's possible the Mara seized temporary control and brought itself home. Now, insert the earpiece, try to relax, and when switched on, listen to the sound.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan puts the box on a wire around her neck and puts in the earpiece.

Dialogue.Line: He thought the only people who knew the truth about the Mara were the Snake Dancers. Once he even took us to visit them. It was miles from anywhere, way up in the hills. It was all wildly unofficial. We had to go in disguise. Can you imagine your father in disguise? Even then.
And did they?
What?
Know the truth about the Mara.

It was so dark and they were so dirty, it was difficult to tell. Oh, they were frightful. They were all covered in ash. Some of them were almost naked. They lived entirely on roots and berries and things, and they put themselves into trances. It was quite disgusting. They handled live snakes, I remember.
Why?
Something to do with their religion.
What did father think?
The Federator, as usual, was not amused.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a knock at the door.

Dialogue.Line: Come in.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A servitor in a short cape shows in a man in mostly Cossack clothing.

Dialogue.Line: Good morning, my Lady Tanha.
Good morning.
Are we ready?
I'm afraid not quite.
I beg your pardon. In that case, I'll
No, no, no, no. Please stay. My son can dress quite quickly.
What's this?
That, my Lord, is a small token in honour of your presence here deputising for your father. I trust you approve?
Thank you.
Exquisite, isn't it?
Is it a fake?
Oh no, my Lord, it's an original. One of a pair from my collection. Seven hundred years old from the middle Sumaran era. I unearthed it myself.
Did you really?
Yes, my Lord.
Oh. Here, then. Catch.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lon doesn't really throw the statuette at Ambril.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, my Lord.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lon finally gets up to leave, and tosses the statuette at Ambril, who fortunately catches it.
Tegan is lying down on the bed in a trance. Nyssa is watching from a peacock chair in the corner.

Dialogue.Line: Where are you now?
On Deva Loka, the Kinda world.
What are you doing there?
It's horrible. Is that thing inside my head? You must know I climbed a tree and dropped apples on its head. No. I will never agree to what you ask. Doctor? Am I free of the Mara now? Forever? Am I?
You must go deeper, Tegan. Much deeper. Where are you now?

I'm in my garden, silly. Everything grows in my garden. People always come back. I close my eyes, I want them to come back and they do. It always works. I can tell lies too. People don't always notice so I'm safe here.
How old are you?
I'm six, silly.
Tegan, now you must leave your garden.
Oh, why?
And go still deeper. Deeper and further. Much further. Can you hear me? Now, I want you to go into the dream.
No.
Why not?
Because I mustn't.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In the covered souk, a man stands at the entrance to a large, decorated tent.

Dialogue.Line: How about you, sir? Madame, step this way, if you'd be so kind. I invite you to take the most exciting journey of all. The voyage inside. The journey to meet yourself. I address you in the silence of your own hearts. I offer my personal challenge. Dare you bare witness to what the Mara shows? Will you gaze upon the unspeakable? Dare you come face to face with the finally unfaceable? Children half price.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: No takers.

Dialogue.Line: Tegan, you're perfectly safe. You must go into the dream. Where are you now?
Snake mouth. Cave. Out.
Out where?
I'm outside. I'm being fed this image.
Go in.
No! Mustn't.
Tegan, you must go into the cave. We need to know what's there.
Something in here. Over there. Mustn't look. Mustn't ever look. I'm safe if I don't look.
Tegan.
No.
You're perfectly safe. You must look. We need to know what is there.
(Mara) Go away!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan wakes up.

Dialogue.Line: Come face to face with the truth about yourself in the Hall of Mirrors. Come along, please. You, sir. For instance, you, you have the look of a humble seeker after life's truth.
Do I really.
Of course you do. Now, if you'd care to step inside
Do you know who I am?
No, young man. Do tell us. Who are you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ambril and Tanha join Lon.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, I beg your pardon, my Lord, my Lady. I'm sure I didn't mean
Well, what's in there?
In, er?
Yes, what exactly does one face in your shoddy little booth?
Er, mirrors, my Lord.
Mirrors?
Distorting mirrors, that's all. People are amused.
Are they.
Generally, my Lord.
Lon.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The distinguished party and their bodyguard move on.
The Doctor is making adjustments to his hypnosis machine.

Dialogue.Line: That voice, what was it?
The Mara, speaking through Tegan's mouth.
On Deva Loka you said a physical change took place when possessed by a Mara.
It does, as mental resistance weakens. But this time I can prevent it.
How?
With this. It inhibits the production of brainwaves associated with dreaming.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor plugs Tegan's earpiece back into his device.

Dialogue.Line: Then what?
We must find the cave, the snake mouth in the dream.
It's a real place?
Oh, yes. What's more, I would guess it's somewhere nearby.
The main entrance to the cave system itself.
I'd forgotten how impressive it is.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They all go inside.
The Tardis has quietly parked herself behind some decorative hangings.

Dialogue.Line: Now, she will be experiencing total exclusion of all outside sound, so you must be her ears.
She can't dream now. She's awake.
Dreams are occurring in the mind all the time. Come on, we must hurry.
The cave system itself
Hello!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lon's voice echoes back.

Dialogue.Line: It's a natural geological formation worn out of the solid rock over hundreds of thousands of years by the action of an underground river.
Hello!
Lon.
The Chamber of the Mara is the largest natural cavern thus formed, but many of our most important archeological finds
Big, isn't it.
Beg pardon, my Lord?
This place, it's big.
Yes, I suppose it is.
Isn't it. Hello!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is getting directions from a stall holder.

Dialogue.Line: Tegan, are you all right?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: All Tegan can hear is a high-pitched whining.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor?
I was right. It seems there's a cave system near by that fits the description. It's, er, this way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: By a colourful wall painting.

Dialogue.Line: This wall constitutes a valuable record of the Sumaran era. Of course, academic interpretations as to its precise meaning do differ, but by paying scrupulous attention to detail and not allowing our imaginations to run away with us, we can form the glimmerings of an idea as to what the pictograms may mean.
What about the Legend of the Return?
The legend, my Lord?
Do you have an opinion?
Yes, I'm rather afraid I do.
Well?

The Legend of the Return is nonsense. Pure superstitious nonsense, invented by the people simply to give themselves something with which to frighten their children. It has no basis, either speculative or proven, in historical fact.
Extraordinary, isn't it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan stops at the bottom of the steps.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor.
It's the cave from her dream.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes Tegan's arm and leads her up.

Dialogue.Line: Now, there's nothing to be frightened of.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan hears a scream in her head and pulls away.

Dialogue.Line: No!
Doctor, she can't hear you.
Nevertheless, Ambril, your predecessor apparently believed in the legend.
Yes. Now what was that man's name?
His name, my Lady, was Dojjen.
Dojjen. Oh yes, of course, that was it.
What are we going to do? She won't go any further, she's too frightened.
Well, you'll have to stay with her. I'll go into the cave alone.
I'm afraid Dojjen came to believe so many things. He became very erratic towards the end. The real work here was sadly neglected.
The real work?
Yes, my Lord.
Oh, you mean poking about in the ruins and digging for trinkets.
Classified, my Lord. I have tried to reestablish our studies here on a strictly scientific basis.
And I'm sure we're all truly grateful. Shall we proceed to the Chamber of the Mara?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A giant relief of a snake is carved into the end wall, with steps leading up to it.

Dialogue.Line: Exquisite, isn't it.
What was in its mouth?
The Great Crystal, my Lord. Purely decorative.
Where is it now? Is it lost?
Oh no, my Lord. It was removed from its socket when the Mara was destroyed. Traditionally, its safekeeping is the responsibility of the Director.
You.
At present I have that honour, my Lord. The image of the Mara is sculpted out of

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor makes his way along.

Dialogue.Line: Solid rock. It is, as you can see, in the form of a snake, a rearing snake. The imagery is consistent with the middle Sumaran period with only insignificant variation.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor looks at the wall painting briefly, then follows the voice.

Dialogue.Line: In Sumaran three period, the head has a tendency to be less pronounced, but in general
Oh, do be quiet just for a moment. It is horrible.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor keeps out of sight.

Dialogue.Line: I'm very glad the Legend of the Return is just a story. It is, isn't it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor breaks cover.

Dialogue.Line: No, I'm afraid it's not.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The bodyguard twists the Doctor's arm behind his back.

Dialogue.Line: Excuse me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: His tray is full of jointed wooden snakes on sticks.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, no thank you. No, really, not at the moment.
Look.
Yes, it's very good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He waves one in front of Tegan, who screams and runs away.

Dialogue.Line: Tegan! Tegan!
There's no need for this.
This is a private view. You have no business to be here. Have him thrown out.
Wait. At least let the man have his say.
Why, my Lord? The man's clearly deranged.
Is he?
Of course he is.
Lon, I really think the Director should deal with this.
Director? Director of what?
Research effort into the Sumaran era.
Are you indeed? Then you may be able to help
I think not. Throw him out.
Just a moment, Ambril. It has been suggested that I take more interest in our legends. Release him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nyssa loses Tegan in the market.

Dialogue.Line: And where, according to you, is the Mara now?
At present it exists as a latent mental force in the mind of my companion.
Does it.
It's using her dreams to increase its power. Eventually it will take over her mind altogether, but I've put together a device to inhibit this temporarily.
Oh, how very resourceful.
Why don't you come and meet her? She's outside.
My Lord, I must insist
Very well, show us.
Certainly. Follow me. AMBRIL My Lord!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan faints in the market. Nyssa runs back to the caves.

Dialogue.Line: Nyssa!
Is this your companion?
Nyssa, what's the matter?
Doctor, she's gone.
What!
She's gone, apparently.
Where?
She took fright. It all happened so quickly.
You've disappointed me, Doctor. I should have you punished.
Come on.
No, let them go. What's the point?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The woman, whose headdress is arranged so that her face looks like it is surrounded by an open snake's mouth, takes Tegan's earpiece out.

Dialogue.Line: Here, that's better. You can hear me now.
No, I mustn't take it off.
Why ever not? What is it, anyway? What does it do?
I can't, I can't remember. I mustn't, that's all. Where am I?
You passed out. They brought you in here. Are you feeling better?
Yes.
Oh, this is hopeless. What state was she in?
Terrified.
Well, let's go back to the Tardis. She might try and find her way back there.
Who are you, please?
I see into the future. I expect it was all the people.
I expect it was all the people.
Of course, that's what it was. It's easy to get confused in crowds. Anyway, I'm glad you're feeling better.
In that.
What?
You see into the future in that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A crystal ball.

Dialogue.Line: Yes. Well, between you and me, not really, I don't. I pretend. I flutter my fingers, gaze deep into the ball and then
Then?

Then I make something up. Whatever comes into my head. Whatever I think they want to hear. After all, they're paying. Doesn't do any harm. Mind you, it's surprising what does come into your head. Sometimes I surprise myself.
Is it surprise?
What is it? What's the matter? What's wrong?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan laughs the Mara cackle. She is fully taken over.

Dialogue.Line: Is it? Well, look now.
Where can she be?
Well, as long as she's wearing the anti-dream device she should be safe.
And if she's not?
I don't know. I just don't know. Why has the Mara returned? Why now, after so long? What does it want?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: When the seer finishes screaming, Mara Tegan has gone.

Dialogue.Line: We don't know nearly enough. Without more information we are simply blundering around in the dark.
The Tardis databanks?
No, no, no. This is the Mara's homeworld. The answers we need are out there. I'll try the Director of the Research Institute, and you look for Tegan in the market. We'll meet back here.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There's a crowd and a commotion outside the Fortune Teller's booth but Nyssa is talking to another trader.

Dialogue.Line: Well, thank you anyway.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan sneaks up behind Nyssa and taps her on the shoulder.

Dialogue.Line: Tegan!
Come to see the fun?
The fun?
Yes, she's still in there. She screamed and screamed.
Are you all right? Where've you been?
I'm fine. Why shouldn't I be?
You're not wearing the anti-dreaming device.
I took it off. It wasn't necessary.
Tegan, what about the Mara?
Stop fussing. What Mara? Look, here she is. Quick, she mustn't see me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan crouches down as the Seer is gently led away by two men.

Dialogue.Line: You should have seen her face. It was so funny. When she screamed, you could see right down her throat.
Tegan, what's the matter with you? What's been going on? Tegan, look at me.
Nyssa, help me. Help me. I made it appear.
What?
You fool. Leave me alone. Just leave me alone.
Tegan!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ambril is sitting at his desk examining an artefact with a large magnifying glass while a servant lays a dining table at the other end of the room. A young man enters.

Dialogue.Line: Er.
Yes, Chela, what is it?
It could be the man you were talking about.
What man?
The man from the cave.
Oh, that man. No, can't possibly. Tell him to go away.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor enters.

Dialogue.Line: Er, hello.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nyssa chases Tegan through the market place.

Dialogue.Line: I know exactly what you want.
Do you?

Yes, you've come to pester me with some extravagant theory you've dreamed up concerning the Mara, and should I, the Director, fail to take sufficient notice of your colourful improbabilities, it will be the end of civilisation as we know it at least. How am I doing so far, hmm?
Look
Sorry to disappoint you, but, you know, you're hardly the first. For some reason, the study of the Sumaran era has always attracted more than its share of cranks. Particularly when a ceremony's due.
What ceremony?
Commemorating the destruction of the Mara by the Federation. Surprise me. Tell me you didn't know.
When is it to be held?
Tomorrow.
Impossible! It must be called off. At least until my companion is found.
Oh, certainly.
What?
Yes, I'll cancel the whole thing. At once. Now my assistant will show you out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan runs into the Hall of Mirrors, and Nyssa carries on. Tegan comes out, then changes her mind and goes back inside.

Dialogue.Line: Look, the facts are these. First of all, my companion brought us here, to this world, without ever having been here before. Now why should she do that? Why here, why now? Then I used hypnosis to establish the presence of the Mara in her head. You see, she has a recurring dream
A dream?
And in this dream. What is it?
It proves nothing. Merely that he's acquainted with the legend.
The Legend of the Return?
Yes.
Don't encourage him.
Well, tell me! Look, all I want's a little information. What possible harm is there in that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ambril devotes his whole attention to the artefact. The Doctor turns to Chela.

Dialogue.Line: Tell me about the legend.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The distorting mirrors in the Hall have snake decorations round them. Tegan has fun with the first two, but the third shows a snake's skull over her head.

Dialogue.Line: All right, all right, humour him, Chela. But remember, there are no actual facts to impede the full flow of the imagination.
The Legend tells that the Mara was not destroyed by the founders of the Federation, but only banished.
To the Dark Places of the Inside.
Yes.
I'm so sorry. Do go on.
Anyway, according to the Legend, the Mara will return in a dream.
What does it want?
It returns to regain its power over men, when the minds meet again in the Great Crystal.
The Great Crystal?
That's enough.
How can minds meet?
How indeed. Wishy mystical mumbo-jumbo.
What about the Snake Dancers?

It appeals to a certain type of mind. Primitive, lazy, uneducated type of mind. Even my assistant here isn't immune. You'll find that the Legend becomes more and more vague the closer it approaches anything resembling any factual detail.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nyssa is outside the Fortune Teller's booth.

Dialogue.Line: Hello?
Hello?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nyssa enters. She sees the shards of the crystal ball on the table, and almost steps on the anti-dream device on the floor. She picks it up.
A ceremonial helmet with a crest of five faces is on a display stand.

Dialogue.Line: Now take this, for example. It dates from the middle Sumaran era and unusually is mentioned quite specifically in the Legend. Oh, there can be no doubt. The reference is to the Six Faces of Delusion. Now count. One, two, three, four, five. You will observe there are five faces, not six as the Legend would have it. Now, my point is this. I do find it quite extraordinarily difficult to take seriously a Legend that cannot even count accurately. Of course, artistically speaking, it's an entirely different matter. The piece is exquisite. An undoubted masterpiece.
What is it?
Hmm? Headdress.
Try it on.
What?
Try it on.
Certainly not. Whatever for?
Please. I want to show you something, then I'll go and leave you in peace.
Very well.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ambril puts on the headdress.

Dialogue.Line: Well?
Now, count the faces again.
Do as he says.
One, two, three, four, five.
And one makes six. The sixth Face of Delusion is the wearer's own. That was probably the idea, don't you think?
Get out! Go on, get out!
No, please.
Face me.
No. No, I mustn't. I can't.
Face me.
I'm so tired.
Then borrow my strength.
How is it possible?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Hawker, the owner of the Hall of Mirrors, enters in the background.

Dialogue.Line: On the Kinda world, the Mara was repelled by mirrors.
On the Kinda world, I was trapped in a circle of mirrors. There is no circle here.
Why am I so confused?
You're divided against yourself. A stranger in your own mind. You are pathetic. Look at me! I can make up your mind.
No.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan faces her reflection. The snake skull speaks.

Dialogue.Line: Why not? What are you afraid of? Just who do you think you are?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The skull vanishes from the mirror, and the snake tattoo appears on Tegan's right forearm.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor? Take this.
What is it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It is a small blue crystal, like the old man is wearing in his meditations.

Dialogue.Line: The Snake Dancers use them in their rituals. They call them Little Mind's Eye. In the Legend, the Great Crystal is named as the Great Mind's Eye.
Indeed.
Perhaps there's a connection. Perhaps they're even made of the same substance. I don't know, Ambril refused to let me run the tests.
Why are you telling me this?
I must go.
Do you believe in the Legends?
No, of course not.
One more question. Who are the Snake Dancers?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But Chela is gone. The crowd turn to stare at the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Highly convincing, young lady. A trick, of course. Voice projection, the art of the ventriloquist perhaps, but in different registers. Oh, very original, all in all. Various possibilities present themselves immediately, should you be, er, along the lines of a partnership. A booth, perhaps and so forth. And me outside enticing the passer-by. Talking them in, relieving them at the door of some small token of their sincere interest. You inside in the half dark, talking away to yourself and scaring them all half to death. Highly satisfactory all round. What do you think?
Nyssa!
Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor holds up the crystal.

Dialogue.Line: I saw Tegan. I spoke to her.
Well, where is she now?
She ran away from me. I lost her in the crowd. But Doctor, look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nyssa hands him the anti-dream device.

Dialogue.Line: She was behaving very oddly.
Was she marked?
I don't
On her arm. The mark of the snake.
I didn't look, I didn't notice.
It must be the Mara. Come on.

Enough's enough. I said I was impressed, as impressed as I need to be. I'm not a curious man. I was once, a long time ago. I was a humble student of life's mysteries. A treader of the secret pathways, a delver into the darker corners and so forth. All rubbish, of course. At the end of the day, when the lights come up, as in one form or another they always do, there's always somebody standing there with their hand out, waiting to be paid. I decided long ago that person might as well be me. Or, in present circumstances, us.
Us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan talks with her unaccented Mara voice.

Dialogue.Line: Who exactly are you? You're not important. There is only one. Only he matters more than what is to be done here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lon is lying on the chaise longue, again. Tanha enters, followed by a servant carrying her golden cloak.

Dialogue.Line: I'm not coming.
Good.
I beg your pardon?

What does he mean, evil? Who is evil?
Oh, I am, Mother. Isn't it obvious? Your son is evil. After all, why else would they want to kill me. Don't you see?
I most certainly do. Take them away. Take all of them away.
No, I think we can afford to be generous on today of all days. At least let them see the Great Crystal just once, just for a moment, don't you think?
My Lord.
Indulge me. That's close enough. Right.
Shall I?
If you wouldn't mind.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ambril raises the lid of the box.

Dialogue.Line: Now!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Nyssa run for the door while Chela tries to get the Crystal away from Lon, who has picked up the box.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, there's no time for that!
Well, don't just stand there, after them!
Me?
Yes, you, and take that fool with you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They hide behind a stall.

Dialogue.Line: Where are we going?
To find Tegan.
We don't even know if she's still alive.
Tegan won't die until the Mara within her is free.
If Lon has been affected by the Mara, why hasn't he changed?
Same reason as Tegan. He still has a lot of his own personality.
But he is influenced?
Very much so.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A guard walks past.

Dialogue.Line: Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lon holds the Great Crystal, which is still only a fraction of the size of the Metabelis crystal. Ambril enters.

Dialogue.Line: Well?
No sign, my Lord. I'm afraid they seem to have got away.
Do they.
Yes. I've issued the necessary instruction. A search party is being organised.
It doesn't matter. What can they do now?
As you say, my Lord.
Well?
I only wish to remind you, my Lord
I've not forgotten.
Our arrangement.
Yes.
You promised immediately after the ceremony, my Lord.
Go away.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ambril leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Lon, what arrangement? What did you promise him?
Nothing, Mother. It doesn't matter.
I know you, you're planning something. Is it to be a surprise?
Yes, Mother.
In here.
It's all right, I think we've managed to lose them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A masked figure jumps out and shakes its maracas at them. They all yelp.

Dialogue.Line: I'm sorry, Doctor, it's just the surprise.
What is it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The figure touches the Doctor with a maraca.

Dialogue.Line: You've been touched by an attendant demon. You must forfeit a coin. It's the custom, I'm afraid.
Custom?
On the day of the ceremony, the attendant demons seek out the unwary. Anyone they touch with the evil must pay up or, er.
Or what?
Have water tipped over their heads. It's part of the fun.
I'm afraid I don't have a coin.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chela pays up for the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Here you are. May you never feel the serpent's tooth.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The 'demon' rattles its maracas and leaves.

Dialogue.Line: I wish it was that easy.)
Doctor, what are we going to do?
How long have we got? When does the actual ceremony begin?
Well, first the Great Snake is taken in procession through the streets before going up to the cave.
How long?
A few hours.
I wonder if there's still time. There must be. It's our only hope. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor puts the Little Mind's Eye round his neck.

Dialogue.Line: Where are we going?
Change of plan. To find Dojjen.
But if it's nothing, why won't you let me see it?
I told you, Mother, it's just a scratch.
It could become infected. How did it happen? Why didn't you tell me?
It was an accident.
What sort of an accident? I would just like to check
Mother! For the last time, will you leave me alone!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The procession has begun, and the snake we saw earlier being laid out on the ground is accompanied by a man with a megaphone.

Dialogue.Line: Now the Great Snake has come to claim his own. Who has the power to turn away his face? Which one of you has the strength to turn away? Who can protect us now? Submit! Submit!
Come on.
If you'd let me steal the Great Crystal, this trek wouldn't be necessary.
It's not as simple as that.
Why not?
We wouldn't be preventing the Mara's return, only postponing it. It would continue to exist as a mental force. No, this time we must destroy it completely.
But how?
I don't know.
And you think Dojjen will be able to tell us?
I hope so.
Dojjen hasn't been seen for ten years. He could be anywhere, assuming he's still alive.
You're forgetting we do have this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The crystal.

Dialogue.Line: How will that help to find him?
It won't. It will help him find us. Trust me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ambril enters carrying a golden headdress with a 'little' crystal in it, and followed by a servant bearing a cushion with some regalia on it.

Dialogue.Line: Well?
I've taken the liberty of bringing the costume that you must wear for the ceremony, my Lord.
Oh good. Look, Mother.
It's an exact replica of the costume worn by your ancestor, the Founder of the Federation, when he destroyed the Mara five hundred years ago.
How very appropriate.
I beg your pardon, my Lord?
Don't you think so, Mother?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tanha stands at the window with her back to them, very still.

Dialogue.Line: Well, I'm going to try it on. Are you coming?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lon picks up the box containing the Great Crystal, and leaves. The servant follows.
Looking just like the place where Dojjen has been seen meditating, except there is no one here.

Dialogue.Line: How far are we going?
This should be fine.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sits on the ground.

Dialogue.Line: What now?
Sympathetic resonance.
Doctor?
Thought directed at this crystal should set up a resonance which is picked up and echoed by another.
So?
Well, the Snake Dancers wear these, don't they?
So I gather.
Of course. The crystal will act like a radio wave, transmitting thoughts instead of words.
Establishing a mental link.
Hopefully.
Will it work?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor closes his eyes and concentrates. The crystal begins to glow. There is a hum, then it fades.

Dialogue.Line: Well?
Now we wait.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lon has returned in a bizarre short white tunic with blue clouds on it, the gold sunburst headdress with blue crystal, gold roman sandals and red gauntlets.

Dialogue.Line: Mother?
Let me look at you.
Am I forgiven?
What? Oh yes, of course. Aren't you always? Come here.
Well, what do you think?
You look splendid. It fits exactly, don't you think so?
Remarkable fit, my Lady, truly remarkable.
Let me look at you. Oh, I am going to be so proud.
If what you say is true, why didn't Dojjen destroy the Great Crystal while he was still Director?
Good question. Nyssa asked exactly the same thing.
Well?
I don't know. Perhaps we'll find that out too.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The crystal glows.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A skinny old man with a large staff and a bag has arrived.

Dialogue.Line: Dojjen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The snake is still whirling amongst the crowd.

Dialogue.Line: Abandon yourselves and follow the path of the snake. Follow the path. Who dare resist the power of the snake?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dojjen sits opposite the Doctor, takes a small snake out of his bag and lets it bite his wrist. Then he hands it to the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, no. What are you doing?
I'm afraid we have no choice if we're to have any hope of saving Tegan.
But its bite could be deadly.
Yes, I do know. (And he puts the snake to his wrist.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ambril leads Lon, Tanha and a guard through the cheering crowd outside the cave, followed by local dignitaries.

Dialogue.Line: No, look into my eyes. You have come this far. You must not now give in to fear. Look.
It's the poison. The effect of the poison.
Fear is the only poison. DOCTOR [OC] Fear is.
Ask your question.
How, how can, I must save Tegan. It was my fault, so how, how can. Destroyed. How can the Mara? It was my fault.
Steady your mind. Attach to nothing. Let go of your fear.
What is the Snake Dance?
This is, here and now. The dance goes on. It is all the dance, everywhere and always. So, find the still point. Only then can the Mara be defeated.
The still point? The point of safety? A place in the chamber somewhere. Where?
No, the still point is within yourself, nowhere else. To destroy the Mara you must find the still point. Point. Point. Point. Point.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lon is studying a scroll very intently.

Dialogue.Line: The snake is approaching, my Lady. We should take our seats.
Yes, certainly.
My Lord, the Great Crystal.
I will tell you when.
Very well, my Lord.
Following the path of the great snake. Submit! Abandon yourselves and follow in the path of the great snake.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The man leads the snake up the steps to the cave.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor? Oh, thank goodness. I thought for a moment
Thought what? No, I survived.
But how?
I don't know. Somehow he saw me through.
We must hurry.
Yes, of course. The ceremony.
Did you find out what you needed to know?
I think I did, we'll have to see. I just hope we're not too late.
Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They bow to Dojjen.
The man leads the snake in to applause and laughter.

Dialogue.Line: Who will challenge the Mara? Who will pluck the Great Crystal of knowledge from between the Mara's jaws and set us free?
(sotto) Lon.
Not yet, my Lady.
For the second time I will ask it. For the third and final time.
I will.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Cheers.

Dialogue.Line: Bring the stranger forward. You dare to challenge the power of the Mara?
I do.
And in whose name do you wish to do so?
In the name of the Federation, and in my own.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Cheers.

Dialogue.Line: First, let the stranger prove his worthiness. Prepare him for the test.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lon removes his left gauntlet.

Dialogue.Line: Are you ready to face the triple temptation?
I am ready.
The first temptation is fear. I offer you fear in a handful of dust.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dust is poured from a skull into Lon's left palm.

Dialogue.Line: I do not fear. I spread my fingers and the dust trickles away. I know that whilst I live my hand is clean, my eyes are bright. That is enough.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nyssa is pushing her way through shrubbery.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, jump.
Thank you. It wasn't necessary.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They go into the cave.

Dialogue.Line: The second temptation.
I am ready.
The second temptation is to despair. I offer you despair in a withered branch.
I do not despair. I turn my hand and the branch drops to the earth. I know the sap will rise again and the roots will sprout. That is enough.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Applause.

Dialogue.Line: Shush.
The ceremony must have started.
Well, let's hope we're not too late.
Doctor, look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A guard blocks the passageway.

Dialogue.Line: The third and final temptation is to succumb to greed. Stranger, now you must look into the crystal without greed for knowledge. I offer you greed in the hidden depths.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lon reaches for the gem in the snake's mouth. The crowd gasps.

Dialogue.Line: My Lord, you must not touch it. Not yet.
Why mustn't I?
The crystal of knowledge has hidden depths.
What do you mean, hidden depths. Where are they? Show them to me. It's just a fake. Your whole ceremony is a fake.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lon takes the crystal from the snake's mouth.

Dialogue.Line: It's nothing. It's just glass.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lon smashes the crystal on the floor.
The guard moves forward.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, come on. Hurry up.
A childish fake at the centre of a farce created by a civilisation that has gone soft. Today I bring real knowledge. Real knowledge and real power. Give it to me.
My Lord, I really do think
Give me the Great Crystal.
Lon, no, please. What is wrong with you?
Mother, let go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lon removes the right gauntlet to reveal the snake on his arm.

Dialogue.Line: What is that?
Now, give me the Great Crystal.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard draws his sword and approaches the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Now!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nyssa and Chela grab the guard and knock him out.

Dialogue.Line: You left that a bit late.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lon goes up to the wall sculpture.

Dialogue.Line: Now listen to me, all of you. I hold in my hands the Great Crystal. The Great Crystal that was removed from its socket by my ancestor, when the Mara was banished to the dark places of the inside. Now, after five hundred years, the Mara has returned. It's fitting that it should be I who restores the Great Crystal to its rightful owner.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lon opens the secret doorway and Tegan comes out, holding the snake.

Dialogue.Line: Go on, do it now.
No! No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Too late. Lon inserts the Crystal, and energy lines stream out towards Tegan. A noise fills the chamber and the audience grab their heads in pain. All except the Doctor. Tegan comes down the steps and puts the snake on the floor where it grows.

Dialogue.Line: No! No more, you must not look! The Mara is feeding off the fear and panic. It needs it. You must not believe what you see. The Great Crystal is absorbing the belief and creating the Mara. Don't look! Reach inside yourselves and find the still point. Oh Nyssa, Nyssa.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor stares into his crystal. The giant snake appears to absorb Tegan, so that just her face is visible in its gaping jaws.

Dialogue.Line: What is happening? Who dares to interrupt the Becoming? Who does not believe? Submit. All minds must submit. Look at me. You must look at me. You cannot resist. It is impossible. No! Stop him! He must be stopped. Help me, Doctor. What's happening to me? Please, look at me, Doctor. I need your help.
No, I will not submit.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dojjen's face appears in his crystal.

Dialogue.Line: No! The crystal! Destroy the crystal! It will prevent my

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Hawker grabs at the Doctor's crystal. There is a hissing sound, he screams and falls. Lon tries, and his hand is burnt too.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you.

Dialogue.Character: (The Doctor runs up the steps and pulls the Great Crystal from its socket. The Mara screams. The snake shrinks and dissolves. Tegan collapses. The crowd are freed from its influence. Dojjen walks away from the ruins. The Doctor goes and sits next to Tegan, who is back to her old Aussie self and crying. TEGAN
Dialogue.Line: It was awful. It was awful. DOCTOR: It's all right. It's all over now. TEGAN: The feelings of hate and rage. It was terrible. I wanted to destroy everything. DOCTOR: Well, you're free of it now. TEGAN: The Mara's gone for ever? DOCTOR: Yes. The Mara has been destroyed.
